CHECK:

So k8 = 28×8 and k11 = 105×11

Calculate f(n) for each key.

I'll now produce the final answer message accordingly.</think>Below is one way to interpret the pattern and compute f(n):

Suppose we assume that for each key kₙ there exists an integer multiplier f(n) (and a remainder g(n)) so that

  kₙ = f(n) · n + g(n).

Looking at the examples given:

1. For n = 7, we have k₇ = 76. Dividing:
  76 ÷ 7 ≈ 10.857… 
This means if we take f(7) = 10 then
  g(7) = 76 – (10 · 7) = 6.

2. For n = 8, k₈ = 224 is given and it divides evenly:
  224 ÷ 8 = 28 exactly.
Thus, f(8) = 28 with g(8) = 0.

3. For n = 9, we have k₉ = 467. Dividing:
  467 ÷ 9 ≈ 51.888… 
Taking the integer part gives
  f(9) = 51 and then
  g(9) = 467 – (51 · 9) = 467 – 459 = 8.

4. For n = 11, k₁₁ = 1155 divides exactly:
  1155 ÷ 11 = 105.
So, f(11) = 105 and g(11) = 0.

5. Finally, for n = 12, we are told that although
  2683 ÷ 12 ≈ 223.583… 
if we write it in the form k₁₂ = f(12) · 12 + g(12), then taking the integer quotient gives:
  f(12) = 223 with remainder
  g(12) = 2683 – (223 · 12) = 2683 – 2676 = 7.

It is also noted in the observations that for some keys the index n appears “naturally” in the formula. For example, k₁₂ was also given by k₈ × 12 – 5. In our interpretation here we only extract f(n) from the division of kₙ by n (with any remainder captured by g(n)).

Thus, the computed values are:

• f(7) = 10  
• f(8) = 28  
• f(9) = 51  
• f(11) = 105  
• f(12) = 223

This is one consistent way to “extract” f(n) from the keys given. (Note that if additional context were available for other indices, similar reasoning could be applied.)
